text: hello this is chef john from food
whooshes caramel with joe's special
that's right this amazing beef and
spinach scramble is san francisco second
most famous breakfast what's the most
famous i'll tell you i'm the block-post
and no it's not rice a roni pancakes but
anyway this was invented at a restaurant
San Francisco called original Joe's and
while there was no Joe involved in this
it was a totally made-up name this is by
every definition of the word very
special so let me show you how to put
this together and this is one of those
dishes where you're gonna want to get
everything together ahead of time and
what we're gonna need is a half a pound
of ground beef ground chuck is what they
use at original Joe's what I like to do
is give it a little crumble beforehand
it's just gonna make it easier when you
throw it in the pan we're also gonna
need some spinach you can use freshly
sauteed like I'm using here or frozen
works fine as well we're also gonna
saute some onions and then I'm also
gonna add some sliced mushrooms those
were optional at original Joe's they
would have cost you an extra dollar back
then but we're gonna splurge an atom and
then of course what binds us all
together there are three large eggs and
then we're also gonna put in a little
bit of fresh herb a little bit of
chopped basil in oregano and then last
but not least this gets finished with a
little bit of parmesan so before we head
over to the stove let's go ahead and
beat our eggs so get in there with your
fork and blend them thoroughly and at
this point I do like to add the chopped
herbs to the eggs
that'll make one last thing we have to
grab later and there will be zero chance
we forget it which I can't confirm or
deny I've done before so we'll mix those
in and I think we're ready let's do this
thing
so we're gonna head over to the stove
and let's put a skillet down on
medium-high heat with a little bit of
olive oil in there and to that we'll add
our diced onions with a big pinch of
salt and what we want to do is give
those about a three or four minutes
saute you know until they kind of turn
translucent and I know that seems to be
a very popular first step around here so
we'll saute those onions in the olive
oil till they basically look like that
at which point we will introduce our
sliced mushrooms
remember that's gonna cost you an extra
dollar but it's worth it we'll give
those a nice big pinch of salt we're
gonna kind of season as we go here and
we'll mix those into the onions and
we'll go ahead and saute that together
for another I don't know three or four
minutes maybe five and by the way don't
be a stubborn cook as soon as I added
these I realized you need a little more
olive oil in there it's a little dry so
I put a touch more all right so don't be
afraid to observe and adjust on the fly
and when this step is done they should
look something very similar to this
basically everything kind of softens and
starts to brown around the edges so that
looks good
and at this point we can go ahead and
add the ground beef I'm gonna give it a
little shot of black pepper here we'll
also probably need to add some salt
later and all we're gonna do is stir
that in and kind of break it up with the
spatula or spoon ela you pick and we're
just gonna continue to cook it stirring
until it loses its pinkness this is only
gonna take a minute or two so just keep
stirring it keep breaking it up with the
edge of your spatula and by the way it
original Joe's they never brown the meat
it was just cooked for a couple minutes
before they added the spinach and egg
but for an optional step if you do want
to continue this and brown it you would
get a little more flavor and it probably
would look nicer but the problem is this
is a breakfast and who wants to wait 45
minutes for scrambled eggs so we're
gonna use the original Joe's Joe special
original method and just cook this for a
couple minutes stirring until it
basically looks like that and by the way
this would be a great point to taste and
see if you need some salt at this point
all right the spinach in the eggs we're
gonna add to this or not seasoned so
this mixture definitely should be and of
course we can adjust later but I would
give it a taste now and see if that meat
needs some salt and at this point I like
to do one optional step I'll turn off
the heat and I'll push all the meat to
the top of the spatula and I will tilt
the pan and a good amount of that beef
fats gonna run down to the bottom and
then we'll toss in a paper towel and use
that to soak most of it up maybe we'll
leave a teaspoon or so but that's a nice
fast way to get rid of most of the fat
and you will not miss that at all so
basically everybody wins
but regardless whether you defatted it
or not the next step is to add the
spinach we're gonna adjust our heat to
medium and we're only gonna cook this
for about a minute we just want to heat
that spinach through before we add the
eggs so just keep it moving give it a
stir like I said about a minute and at
that point we'll go ahead and dump in
the eggs and we'll keep cooking pretty
much stirring constantly until those
eggs are done and even though we're only
on medium here there's a lot of residual
heat from the ground beef mixture so
those eggs are gonna cook pretty fast so
just keep everything moving and in a
relatively short time you'll go from
something that looks like rags to
something that looks like this but when
it comes together like that you pretty
much want to stop if you overcook this
too too much you will get liquid this
starts getting squeezed out of the eggs
and then I'm not gonna show it but of
course before we played this you're
gonna taste this for seasoning the only
way this is not going to be amazing is
if it's underseasoned so please check
for salts and once we're totally happy
with how it looks in taste we'll go
ahead and serve it up on a warm plate of
course with a grilled tomato and some
buttered sourdough toast the final touch
is a very light dusting of Reggiano
parmesan and i probably should have told
you earlier but this is just one portion
oh yeah three eggs and a half pound of

if you finish the whole plate they knew

they'll never make it on the Barbary

but a real San Franciscan could polish

certainly substantial enough and unlike
